questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not caused by Staphylococcus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Erysipelas is a bacterial infection of the dermis and upper subcutaneous tissue; its hallmark is a well-defined raised edge reflecting the more superficial (dermal) involvement.
  • Classic aetiology: Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes), not Staphylococcus species.
  • Infection begins through minor skin breaches (e.g., tinea pedis, eczema) and spreads rapidly within lymphatic channels.
  • Histology shows diffuse dermal oedema, neutrophilic infiltrate, dilated lymphatics, and occasional dermal-epidermal separation without primary vasculitis or thrombosis.
  • Most common in the very young, the elderly, the debilitated, and those with chronic cutaneous ulcers or lymphatic obstruction (e.g., lymphedema).
  • Clinical features:
    • Incubation: 2-5 days post-inoculation.
    • Systemic: Abrupt onset of high fever, chills, malaise, nausea; patients may be toxic.
    • Cutaneous: Sharply demarcated, raised, bright red plaque with non-pitting oedema and burning sensation.
    • Lymphatic involvement: Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Possible vesicles, bullae, or small hemorrhagic necrosis in severe cases; resolves with desquamation and pigment changes.
  • Treatment
    • First-line: Penicillin V (oral) or Penicillin G (IV) for 10-14 days to ensure bactericidal levels in dermis.
    • Penicillin-allergic alternatives:
      1. Macrolides (erythromycin, azithromycin) - monitor local resistance.
      2. Clindamycin is used for toxin inhibition; check for inducible resistance.
    • Supportive:
      1. IV fluids and vasopressors for hypotension.
      2. Analgesics and limb elevation to reduce oedema.
      3. Monitor for bullae rupture, secondary bacteremia, or progression to necrotising infection.
    • Recurrent cases: Low-dose penicillin prophylaxis (e.g., benzathine penicillin G IM every 2-4 weeks) for ≥2 episodes/year, plus management of underlying lymphedema or skin breaches.

Explanation of other options:

  • Scalded skin syndrome (Option A) is caused by Staphylococcus aureus strains producing exfoliative toxins A and B and leads to widespread superficial skin desquamation.
  • Ecthyma (Option B) is often due to Staphylococcus aureus (bullous) or Streptococcus pyogenes. It presents as deeper ulcers with erythematous margins and yellow-brown crust.
  • Impetigo (Option D) - Bullous impetigo is caused by Staphylococcus aureus exfoliative toxins. Non-bullous impetigo involves both Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes, with honey-colored crusts.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy developed perioral crusted plaques accompanied by mild itching after his classmate had similar lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Impetigo is a common infection of the superficial layers of the epidermis that is highly contagious and most commonly caused by gram-positive bacteria.

Non-bullous Impetigo

  • Nonbullous impetigo is caused by S aureus and Group A beta-hemolytic Strep (GABHS).
  • It often starts as a vesicle or a pustule, and then ruptures, after which the purulent exudate forms the characteristic golden yellow honey-colored crust. An erythematous base is also present.
  • MC site: face
  • It is highly contagious and can spread rapidly in close contact settings.

Characteristic features of bullous and non-bullous impetigo

Explanation of other options:

  • Bullous Impetigo (Option A) presents with large flaccid bullae caused by exfoliative toxin A of S. aureus, not honey-colored crusts.
  • Herpes labialis (Option C) is characterised by grouped vesicles on an erythematous base around the lips, caused by HSV-1 1 not honey-colored crusts on the face.
  • Erysipelas (Option D) is an acute skin infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics, causing well-demarcated, raised, bright red plaques, not crusted lesions.

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, Page Number: 26.13

questions.text: The following conditions are complications of streptococcal impetigo except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rheumatic fever has never been shown to occur after streptococcal pyoderma.
  • Rheumatic fever is more strongly associated with streptococcal pharyngitis.
  • Streptococcal impetigo (pyoderma) can lead to systemic sequelae via immune-mediated mechanisms.

Complications of streptococcal impetigo

  • Scarlet Fever (Option A)
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option B)
  • Erythema nodosum (Option C)
  • Erythema multiforme

ARF pathophysiology: aberrant immune response 2 - 4 weeks post throat infection → carditis, valvulitis, Sydenham chorea, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, migratory polyarthritis.

choices.text: Caused by both Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the disease shown below is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bullous impetigo produces subcorneal (intraepidermal) bullae due to exfoliative toxin A cleaving desmoglein-1 in the superficial epidermis.
  • The toxin causes loss of cell adhesion between keratinocytes, leading to flaccid bullae with purulent fluid collected in the lower half (hypopyon sign).
  • After rupture, thin, flat crusts are formed.
  • Predominantly affects infants and children <2 years
  • If the toxin disseminates, there is a risk of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) in vulnerable patients.

Explanation of other options:

  • Regional lymphadenopathy (Option B) is uncommon in bullous impetigo; systemic signs are typically minimal.
  • Honey-colored crusts (Option C) characterise non-bullous impetigo; bullous impetigo initially presents with larger, fluid-filled bullae.
  • Bullous impetigo is caused almost exclusively by Staph. Aureus - not by Strep. pyogenes. (Option D)

choices.text: Staphylococcal infection of the follicular ostium
Chronic scarring form of sycosis barbae

questions.text: Bockhart's impetigo refers to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Superficial folliculitis (follicular impetigo of Bockhart) is an infection of the follicular ostium with S. aureus.
  • Use of topical steroids or local trauma is a predisposing factor
  • Presents as folliculocentric papules and pustules on an erythematous base, often pruritic or tender.
  • Treatment is directed by culture results: topical antibacterial preparations (e.g., mupirocin or benzoyl peroxide) for localised lesions and oral antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline) if widespread.

Explanation of other options:

  • Sycosis barbae (Option B) is deep folliculitis of the beard area and causes scarring, not synonymous with Bockhart's.
  • Perforating folliculitis of the nose (Option C) is unrelated to Bockhart's.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis (Option D) presents as widespread pruritic papulopustules after water exposure, not impetigo of Bockhart.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of follicular pyodermas
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Staphylococcus aureusis the most common pathogen of follicular pyodermas (folliculitis, furuncles and carbuncles).
  • It colonises hair follicles and produces factors that promote inflammation and pus formation.
  • Gram-negative pathogens, including Klebsiella, Enterobacter, and Proteusspecies, may replace the gram-positive flora on facial skin, nasal mucous membranes, and neighbouring areas, causing gram-negative folliculitis and boils.
  • 'Hot tub' folliculitis is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosacontamination of undertreated water in saunas or whirlpools.
  • Deep follicular infections (e.g., sycosis barbae) may lead to scarring and require systemic therapy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Option B) can cause non-bullous impetigo and erysipelas, but it is a less frequent cause of primary folliculitis.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C) causes “hot tub” folliculitis in settings of contaminated water but is not the most common etiologic agent overall.
  • Propionibacterium acnes (Cutibacterium acnes) (Option D) is implicated in acne vulgaris, not typically in acute pyogenic folliculitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of diabetes presents with a 3-day history of a painful lesion as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A boil, also known as a furuncle, is a bacterial infection involving the hair follicle and perifollicular tissue.
  • It appears as a painful red swelling around the follicular opening and may progress to form an abscess.
  • Furuncles occur when aureus invades a hair follicle, → perifollicular abscess formation.
  • Most common in adolescents and young adults, and predisposing factors include diabetes, obesity, poor hygiene, and immunodeficiency.
  • Common sites: face, neck, axillae, buttocks, thighs, perineum (areas of friction and abundant follicles).

Treatment:

  • Warm compresses to promote maturation and spontaneous drainage.
  • Incision and drainage (I&D) if fluctuant and culture pus for antibiotic guidance.
  • Empiric antibiotics if:
    • Furuncle is located in a high-risk area (face, external auditory canal, hands, genitalia).
    • Multiple sites or associated cellulitis.
    • Immunocompromised host or comorbidities.
    • Lesions are not responding to local measures.
  • Common empiric agents: Doxycycline or clindamycin.

Explanation of other options:

Erysipelas is a non-follicular, lymphatic, dermal infection with sharply bordered erythema. (Option D)

questions.text: A 65-year-old uncontrolled diabetic presents with a painful lesion on the neck. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A carbuncle is a deep infection of a group of contiguous follicles with Staph. Aureus, accompanied by intense inflammatory changes in the surrounding and underlying connective tissues, including the subcutaneous fat.

  • They typically present as an erythematous, tender, inflamed, fluctuant nodule with multiple draining sinus tracts or pustules on the surface.
  • Systemic symptoms are usually present, and regional lymphadenopathy may occur.
  • They can arise in any hair-bearing location on the body; however, they are most common in areas with thicker skin, such as the posterior neck, back, and thighs.

Predisposing conditions that lead to a compromised or broken-down skin barrier include eczema, diabetes mellitus, alcohol use disorder, malnutrition, immunodeficiency, obesity, and poor hygiene.

Treatment:

  • I&D of the entire lesion, including debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Systemic antibiotics are recommended due to deeper, extensive infection and a higher risk of bacteremia.
  • Empiric MRSA coverage (e.g., TMP-SMX or clindamycin), adjust based on culture.

Erythrasma is a superficial Corynebacterium minutissimum infection, well-demarcated brownish patch with coral-red fluorescence under Wood’s lamp. (Option C)

Cellulitis is a diffuse infection of the dermis/subcutis; poorly demarcated erythema and oedema without follicular involvement or central necrosis. (Option D)

questions.text: What is the most common cause of acute paronychia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paronychia is an infection of the proximal and lateral fingernail and toenail folds, including the tissue that borders the root and sides of the nail.
  • This condition can occur spontaneously or following trauma or manipulation. Results from the disruption of the protective barrier (cuticle) between the nail and the nail fold, introducing bacteria and predisposing the area to infection.

The classification of paronychia is according to the clinical presentation:

  • Acute paronychia - Lasting less than six weeks, painful and purulent condition; most frequently caused by a bacterial infection, especially staphylococci.
  • Chronic paronychia - Usually caused by mechanical or chemical factors and sometimes an infectious aetiology like a fungal infection, especially Candida species. Risk factors include occupation (dishwasher, bartender, housekeeper), certain medications, and immunosuppression (diabetes, HIV, malignancy).

Explanation of other options:

  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Option B) can cause acute paronychia, but less common than S. aureus.
  • Candida albicans (Option C) is associated with chronic paronychia, not the most common acute cause.
  • Trichophyton rubrum (Option D) is a dermatophyte causing onychomycosis, not a typical cause of acute paronychia.

questions.text: A patient presented with paronychia and a lesion on the arm as shown in the image. Which of these is the most suitable antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Paronychia is an infection of the proximal and lateral fingernail and toenail folds, including the tissue that borders the root and sides of the nail.
  • Acute Paronychia is caused by Staphylococcus aureus most commonly.
  • Acute paronychia may be accompanied by fever, lymphangitis and tender lymphadenopathy.
  • Lymphangitis presents as a painful linear streak on the arm, indicating spread of a staphylococcal infection via lymphatic channels.
  • Acute paronychia with lymphangitic streak =indicates staphylococcal involvement; treat with β–lactamase–stable antibiotics such as amoxicillin-clavulanate.
  • Recognise lymphangitis as a marker of lymphatic spread requiring prompt systemic therapy.

Explanation of other options:

  • Amikacin (Option B) primarily targets Gram-negative bacilli; not first-line for staphylococcal skin infections.
  • Norfloxacin (Option C) Fluoroquinolone with limited Gram-positive coverage; not ideal for S. aureus.
  • Metronidazole (Option D) Active against anaerobes and protozoa; no activity against S. aureus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with type 2 diabetes reports persistent scaly patches in his armpit as shown below. He has no complaints of itching or burning at the site of the rash. What is the diagnostic test used to confirm this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is erythrasma caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, which produces coproporphyrin III, which fluoresces coral-red under Wood’s lamp.

  • Erythrasma is a superficial infection of the skin, typically in the skin folds (toe webs, axillae and groin). Caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.
  • Well well-demarcated hyperpigmented lesion with scaling is located in the skin folds.
  • Wood's lamp: Coral-red fluorescence (Coproporphyrin III production by bacteria).
  • More common in warm, humid environments and individuals with obesity or diabetes.
  • Often mistaken for dermatophyte infection or tinea cruris, the absence of pruritus can help differentiate.
  • Erythrasma responds well to topical erythromycin cream, clindamycin and benzyl peroxide. And topical azoles, e.g. clotrimazole and miconazole

Explanation of other options:

  • KOH mount (Option A) Detects fungal elements (tinea), negative in erythrasma.
  • Slit lamp examination (Option B) Used for ocular surface evaluation, not skin.
  • Slit skin smear (Option D) Used to diagnose leprosy, not erythrasma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cutaneous bacterial infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trichomycosis axillaris is a relatively common superficial corynebacterial colonisation of the axillary hair shafts characterised by the presence of adherent granular concretions and a benign clinical course.

Aetiology: Caused predominantly by Corynebacterium tenuis and Corynebacterium spp.

Clinical features:

  • Visible colored concretions (yellow > black/red) on axillary hair.
  • May have mild malodor or pruritus.
  • Predisposing factors: hyperhidrosis, poor hygiene, humid climates.

Management:

  • Shaving or clipping affected hair shafts to remove concretions.
  • Topical antibacterial soaps or cleansers (e.g., benzoyl peroxide).
  • Topical erythromycin or clindamycin if secondary inflammation.

Explanation of other options:

  • Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option A) neutrophilic dermatoses, rapidly enlarging, painful ulcer
  • Impetigo herpetiformis (Option B) pustular psoriasis of pregnancy
  • Ecthyma contagiosum (Option D) zoonotic viral infection from sheep. Caused by the orf virus

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, back from a trip to the United States, presents with complaints of malaise, headache, rash, and fever. She went hiking in a local park with her family seven days ago. A rash is noted on her right upper extremity. What is the recommended treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete bacterium, Borrelia burgdorferi.
  • It is transmitted after a bite by the Ixodes deer tick.
  • The most common presenting sign of Lyme disease is a circular expanding rash called erythema chronicum migrans. Other early symptoms of Lyme disease include headache, muscle pain, fever, and malaise.
  • A 10-day course of doxycycline is recommended for patients with early, localised disease to eradicate spirochetes and prevent progression.
  • Prevention includes protective clothing, tick repellents, and prompt tick removal (within 36 hours).

Explanation of other options:

  • Penicillin (Option A) Less effective than doxycycline or amoxicillin for Lyme; not recommended.
  • Acyclovir (Option B) Antiviral agent for herpesviruses; no activity against Borrelia.
  • Prednisolone (Option C) Immunosuppressive; may worsen infection and is not indicated in Lyme treatment.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple red, purple, flesh-colored, or colourless papules on the right arm. He is known to be HIV positive. These lesions are caused by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bacillary angiomatosis, a treatable opportunistic infection, was initially reported as an atypical subcutaneous infection in patients with advanced HIV disease and as epithelioid angiomatosis.
  • The agents causing this infection, initially designated as Rochalimaea, have been reclassified as Bartonella.
  • The term bacillary angiomatosis is being replaced by Bartonella infection because the infectious agents causing this condition have been identified as two species of Bartonella - B. henselae and B. Quintana.
  • Bartonella henselae is most often transmitted through a cat scratch or bite, though ticks and fleas may also act as a vector. Bartonella quintana is usually transmitted by lice. It can manifest in people with AIDS and rarely appears in those who are immunocompetent.
  • Lesions appear as friable, lobulated papules or nodules that may bleed easily.
  • Histology: lobular capillary proliferation with neutrophilic infiltrate; Warthin–Starry silver stain highlights bacilli.
  • Treatment: Macrolides (e.g., erythromycin, azithromycin) or doxycycline for 8–12 weeks for cutaneous BA.

Explanation of other options:

  • Bordetella pertussis (Option A) Causes whooping cough, not cutaneous vascular lesions.
  • Rickettsia conorii (Option C) Causes Mediterranean spotted fever with rash, not papular angiomatous nodules.
  • Actinomyces comitans (Option D) Associated with periodontal disease, not vascular skin tumors.

questions.text: Eschar on the back can be seen in all the following except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kyasanur Forest disease is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever; it does not produce a cutaneous eschar.
  • In contrast, Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsial) (Option A), Scrub Typhus (Orientia tsutsugamushi) (Option B), and cutaneous Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) (Option D) can each present with an eschar at the inoculation site.
  • Eschar is a painless, non-itching lesion and is common in warm, damp areas of the body where skin surfaces meet or clothes bind (perineum, groin and axilla). It develops following the bite of mites, which is also painless. Hence, though it can clinch the diagnosis, it often goes unnoticed.
  • All patients presenting with fever and without any localising signs should be examined carefully for eschar.
  • Important differential diagnoses of eschar-forming illness are: spider bite, spotted fever rickettsiosis, tularaemia, anthrax and ecthyma gangrenosum.

questions.text: This clinical finding is caused by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Green nail syndrome (chloronychia) results from colonisation of the nail plate by P. aeruginosa, which produces pyocyanin pigments.
  • Predisposing factors include prolonged moisture exposure, frequent hand-washing, detergents, or mechanical trauma, especially in elderly or immunocompromised patients.
  • The characteristic green-black/greenish-yellow discolouration and distolateral onycholysis follow bacterial growth beneath a partially detached nail.
  • Diagnosis is clinical (green pigmentation) but can be confirmed with culture of nail scrapings.
  • First-line therapy: oral fluoroquinolone (e.g., ciprofloxacin) plus daily antiseptic soaks (chlorhexidine).
  • Preventive measures: keep hands and feet dry, avoid over-immersion in water, and trim onycholytic areas to reduce bacterial load.

Explanation of other options:

  • Klebsiella (Option A) Gram-negative bacillus. Not a typical cause of green nail syndrome.
  • Staphylococcus aureus (Option B) Common cause of acute paronychia and onychia, but does not produce green pigment.
  • Candida (Option C) species are a common cause of chronic paronychia. The nail fold is red and swollen (no green discolouration).

questions.text:
A 6-month-old girl is brought in with 36h history of high fever, poor feeding and progressive lethargy. On arrival, she is tachycardic and hypotensive. Examination reveals a rapidly enlarging, irregular purpuric rash over both lower limbs (see image).
Which immediate drug therapy should be started as first-line?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is Purpura Fulminans.

  • Purpura fulminans represents acute disseminated intravascular coagulation secondary to Neisseria meningitidis septicemia, with microvascular thrombosis and haemorrhage leading to rapidly spreading purpura.
  • Hypotension, shock, and purpura fulminans in an infant mandate immediate empiric coverage against N. meningitidis.
  • High-dose IV ceftriaxone rapidly achieves bactericidal levels in blood and CSF and is the recommended initial therapy.

Meningococcaemia

  • N. meningitidis colonises the human upper respiratory tract and is transmitted by droplets from patients or healthy carriers.
  • Organisms invade capillary endothelium → complement activation → DIC (purpura fulminans) and potential Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (adrenal gland failure secondary to haemorrhagic destruction caused by the N. meningitidis infection)
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by isolation of N. meningitidis from blood or cerebrospinal fluid or by PCR.
  • Management:
    • Circulatory support and intravenous fluids.
    • First line: High-dose IV ceftriaxone or benzylpenicillin.
    • Alternatives: Cefotaxime, meropenem, or chloramphenicol.

Explanation of other options:

  • Vancomycin (Option A) targets gram-positives; ineffective against N. meningitidis.
  • Ciprofloxacin (Option C) oral route too slow and not recommended as first-line in neonates/infants.
  • Acyclovir (Option D) is an antiviral; no role in bacterial purpura fulminans.

choices.text: Often associated with moisture and hyperhidrosis

questions.text: Find the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Skin biopsies are not performed routinely because the diagnosis of pitted keratolysis can be made easily using visual examination and recognition of the characteristic odour.

Pitted Keratolysis:

  • Pitted keratolysis is a superficial bacterial infection of the stratum corneum, presenting as multiple crater-like pits on the plantar surface in weight-bearing regions. (Option A)
  • It occurs when bacteria (primarily Corynebacterium spp.) proliferate under conditions of prolonged occlusion, hyperhidrosis, and increased skin pH, producing proteases that dissolve keratin and create pits. (Option C)
  • It is a common problem among athletes, as heat, sweat, and humidity cause changes in the skin microbiome. (Option B)
  • Skin swab and culture are not done because the causative bacteria are commensals, and any positive findings do not confirm the cause/diagnosis.
  • Management: Limit the use of occlusive footwear and reduce foot friction by wearing properly fitted footwear. Absorbent cotton socks must be changed frequently to prevent excessive foot moisture.
  • Twice-daily applications of erythromycin, clindamycin, or fusidic acid are effective.

questions.text: A 35-year-old tannery worker presents with a painless papule on his right hand that progressed into a black eschar surrounded by tense, non-pitting oedema. He recalls handling animal hides one week ago. He now has a high fever, vomiting, and profuse sweating. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anthrax is an acute disease caused by the bacteria Bacillus anthracis gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium Bacillus anthracis.
  • Cutaneous Anthrax is also known as Malignant Pustule.

Clinical Features

  • Malignant pustule: A form of anthrax infection that begins as a papule that becomes a vesicle and breaks down into an ulcer covered with eschar, with a discharge of toxins; symptoms of septicemia are severe, with vomiting and high fever and profuse sweating; the infection is often fatal.
  • In more than 95% of cases of endemic disease, spores are transmitted from infected animals or their products through skin abrasions

Treatment:

Ciprofloxacin, Doxycycline, Erythromycin, Vancomycin or Penicillin.

  1. In possible cases of inhalation anthrax, early antibiotic prophylaxis treatment is crucial to prevent possible death.
  2. Monotherapy with ciprofloxacin or doxycycline for 14 days (extend to 60 days if aerosol exposure)
  3. Systemic or head/neck disease requires combination therapy.

Anthrax is notifiable; notify public health authorities on suspicion.

Explanation of other options:

  • Ecthyma gangrenosum (Option B) occurs in immunocompromised; painful necrotic ulcer with surrounding erythema in Pseudomonas septicemia, lacks tense oedema and black eschar.
  • Ulceroglandular tularemia (Option C) Tender ulcer + marked regional lymphadenopathy after rabbit/tick exposure; no black eschar or extensive oedema.
  • Orf (milker’s nodule) (Option D) Viral papulonodule in shepherds; pruritic, no systemic symptoms, no eschar formation.

questions.text: A patient from Uttarakhand presented in September with fever and myalgia. The patient was started on IV Ceftriaxone given but it didn't help; later noticed cutaneous lesions were noticed on examination. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Scrub typhus is an acute, febrile, infectious illness that is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.Obligate intracellular gram-negative bacterium
  • O tsutsugamushi,the pathogen that causes scrub typhus, is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected chigger, the larval stage of Leptotrombidiummites.
  • The bacteria multiply at the inoculation site, and a papule forms that ulcerates and becomes necrotic, evolving into an eschar, with regional lymphadenopathy.

Elements brought out in the history may include the following:

  • Travel to an area where scrub typhus is endemic
  • Chigger bite (often painless and unnoticed)
  • Incubation period of 6-20 days (average, 10 days)
  • Headaches, shaking chills, lymphadenopathy, conjunctival injection, fever, anorexia, and general apathy
  • CNS signs and symptoms
  • Rash: a small, painless, gradually enlarging papule, which leads to an area of central necrosis and is followed by eschar formation

Current treatment for scrub typhus is based on antibiotic therapy - Doxycycline is the DOC.

Explanation of other options:

  • Anthrax (Option B) - Painless black eschar with marked zone of oedema. Respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Kyasanur disease (Option C) is a tick-borne viral illness. It features hemorrhagic fever, thrombocytopenia, and hepatic dysfunction, without eschar.
  • Demetitious fungi (Option C) - Superficial skin lesions (scaling/vesicles), pruritic and non-necrotic, no high fever or systemic toxicity.
